awd_titl_txt: The Dynamics of Contracting Gels During Cell Crawling and Blebbing
awd_abstract_narration: In this project the PI will focus on developing a quantitative mathematical model that describes the physics of cytoskeletal deformation coupled to cytosolic fluid flow during cell crawling and then testing this model using nematode sperm as a model system. The project consists of three parts. The first part will use a linear, two-phase, steady state model for the depolymerization-driven motility of nematode sperm as a foundation for construction of a full nonlinear, moving boundary model that describes force generation and flow in these crawling cells. This model will include the permeability of the cell membrane to fluid flow, which is often neglected in models for cell motility. The second aim of the project is to do quantitative experiments to test specific predictions of the model. Using DIC microscopy and a cell tracking algorithm developed in the Wolgemuth lab, experiments will be done to explore how the speed of C. elegans sperm depends on shape and substrate adhesion. In addition, fluorescent beads embedded in elastic substrates will be used to measure the local traction forces generated by the cell. Particle Imaging Velocimetry techniques will be used to measure the cytoskeletal velocities inside the cell. The third aim will test the recently proposed hypothesis that cell blebbing (a process by which hydrostatic pressure differences drive the cytosolic fluid flow to rip the membrane away from the cytoskeleton) may provide some of the protrusive force at the leading edge of crawling cells. To test this hypothesis the PI will develop a new mathematical description of the behavior of the cytoskeleton and cytosol at the leading edge of the cell. Students involved in this research will work at the interface of theory and experiments. The results of this research will be broadly disseminated by publication in interdisciplinary journals and presentations at major international conferences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Many animal cells are able to move from place to place using a process called crawling.  The research funded by this award investigated how the forces that produce cell motility are generated within a cell.  We found that disassembly of the cytoskeleton, which is the main structural component of the cell, can produce sufficient force to propel nematode sperm cells.  This same mechanism may also be applicable to many other types of cells.  For example, we colalborated with Josef Kaes' group in Leipzig to show that some of the force produced by fish keratocytes may also be generated in this fashion.  Interestingly, this mechanism may also be related to how force is produced to separate bacteria when they divide.

Based on some of the findings in this research, we were lead to consider the consequences of the forces that were produced by a cell.  We have shown that a simple description of the forces generated by a cell can deform tissue surrounding cells and that these deformations can influence other cells.  We are currently investigating how this can impact cancer metastasis and wound healing.

Much of the research that we did for this award used a novel computational algorithm that we developed that allows one to simulate a complex moving boundary and solve physics and chemical equations within the moving boundary.  We continued to develop this algorithm and now three other groups are using the algorithm to explroe problems in membrane biophysics and cell motility.

This award partially funded four graduate students, an undergraduate and a postdoctoral researcher.  This grant also supported work that lead to 7 papers.


Last Modified: 10/05/2014
Modified by: Charles W Wolgemuth
